# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Again!One of the things I love (and deeply respect) about the hashtag#UAE is how they periodically drop game-changing policies with quiet confidenceâ€”no fuss, no noise, just commit and go. â© â© â© While some leaders are still clinging to outdated return-to-office mandates, the UAE has just greenlit remote work from OUTSIDE the country for federal employeesâ€”a move that doesnâ€™t just disrupt traditional employment structures but trivialises the very idea of location-based work. # 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Having had the great priviedge of working with a number of directors across UAE government departments, I have experienced first hand how innovative, progressive, and future-focussed they are. # 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Dubai's real estate market maintained its status as a top investment destination last month, with significant annual price increases in residential units, villas, and apartments. The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Dubai's real estate market maintained its status as a top investment destination last month, with significant annual price increases in residential units, villas, and apartments. The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

The UAE just casually rewrote the rulebook on work. Again!One of the things I love (and deeply respect) about the hashtag#UAE is how they periodically drop game-changing policies with quiet confidenceâ€”no fuss, no noise, just commit and go. â© â© â© While some leaders are still clinging to outdated return-to-office mandates, the UAE has just greenlit remote work from OUTSIDE the country for federal employeesâ€”a move that doesnâ€™t just disrupt traditional employment structures but trivialises the very idea of location-based work. Hurrah to that!!! ğŸ¥³ And hereâ€™s the thingâ€”this wonâ€™t have been a shot in the dark.Knowing the UAE (having lived and worked there for 12 years), this decision will be backed by data from their 4.5-day workweek implementation, insights from global talent trends, and a futurist lens that ensures theyâ€™re always ahead of the curve rather than scrambling to catch up. ğŸ“ˆ The UAE just delivered a masterclass in leadership: âœ… Informed, strategic decision-making âœ… Calculated risk-taking with both macro and micro perspectives in mind âœ… No fear, no resistance, no half measuresâ€”just bold, decisive actionIsn't it refreshing? ğŸ‹ The UAE is moving forward, while so many others are stuck looking back.And, in answer to Ahmed AlDhraif's question - Would you work for a government remotely? # 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Dubai's real estate market maintained its status as a top investment destination last month, with significant annual price increases in residential units, villas, and apartments. The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Dubai's real estate market maintained its status as a top investment destination last month, with significant annual price increases in residential units, villas, and apartments. The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

By launching the UTC-UX Fusion, an AI-driven traffic signal control system, Dubai isnâ€™t merely adopting emerging technologiesâ€”itâ€™s setting a new standard for cities worldwide. This system integrates predictive analytics, self-learning algorithms, and digital twin simulations before they become mainstream, embodying the UAEâ€™s ethos of leading from the front. Why This Matters:The UAEâ€™s leadership has always prioritized audacious innovation over incremental progress. From autonomous air taxis to hyperloop concepts, Dubai operates as a living laboratory for transformative ideas. # 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. # 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

# 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Dubai's real estate market maintained its status as a top investment destination last month, with significant annual price increases in residential units, villas, and apartments. The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.

The UAE just casually rewrote the rulebook on work. Again!One of the things I love (and deeply respect) about the hashtag#UAE is how they periodically drop game-changing policies with quiet confidenceâ€”no fuss, no noise, just commit and go. â© â© â© While some leaders are still clinging to outdated return-to-office mandates, the UAE has just greenlit remote work from OUTSIDE the country for federal employeesâ€”a move that doesnâ€™t just disrupt traditional employment structures but trivialises the very idea of location-based work. Hurrah to that!!! ğŸ¥³ And hereâ€™s the thingâ€”this wonâ€™t have been a shot in the dark.Knowing the UAE (having lived and worked there for 12 years), this decision will be backed by data from their 4.5-day workweek implementation, insights from global talent trends, and a futurist lens that ensures theyâ€™re always ahead of the curve rather than scrambling to catch up. ğŸ“ˆ The UAE just delivered a masterclass in leadership: âœ… Informed, strategic decision-making âœ… Calculated risk-taking with both macro and micro perspectives in mind âœ… No fear, no resistance, no half measuresâ€”just bold, decisive actionIsn't it refreshing? ğŸ‹ The UAE is moving forward, while so many others are stuck looking back.And, in answer to Ahmed AlDhraif's question - Would you work for a government remotely? # 13 Tips for Auditing Real Estate  across UAE: 1.Â Ensure compliance with UAE real estate laws RERA (Dubai), ADREC (Abu Dhabi), and other emirate-specific requirements such as real estate policies and governance frameworks.2.Â Â Cross-check legal ownership with the land department and validate any encumbrances or liens.3.Â Assess rental contracts, lease terms, and revenue recognition (IFRS 16) to ensure accuracy.4.Â Evaluate Annual Maintenance Contracts (AMC) and repair agreements for completeness, cost reasonableness, and adherence to service-level agreements (SLAs).5.Â Review payments to vendors and AMC providers to confirm they align with contract terms, approved budgets, and service quality expectations. Verify approvals and supporting documentation before processing payments.6.Â Examine internal approval workflows for vendor payments, maintenance expenses, and capital expenditures. Ensure segregation of duties and compliance with procurement policies.7.Â Scrutinize expense allocations for maintenance, security, and utilities, ensuring transparency and fair distribution among tenants.8.Â Review accounts receivable, aging reports, and tenant payment histories. Identify overdue payments, assess bad debt provisions, and evaluate collection efforts.9.Â Ensure service-level agreements (SLAs) between legal and collections teams are well-defined, outlining responsibilities, escalation procedures, and expected response times for disputes or overdue payments.10. Evaluate the return on investment (ROI) for each building to assess financial performance.11. Track expense trends, looking for any unexplained significant increases, and investigate the justification for those increases.12.Â Check vacancy rates and the effectiveness of marketing strategies in addressing vacancy issues.13. Ensure there is a structured process for handling tenant and owner complaints, with clear reporting lines. Also, monitor any cases filed with Baladiya and ensure timely responses and legal compliance.MAğŸ˜Š

Dubai's real estate market maintained its status as a top investment destination last month, with significant annual price increases in residential units, villas, and apartments. The ValuStrat Price Index recorded its slowest capital growth in 20 months, with villa valuations rising by 2%, down from a peak of 2.7%, and apartment prices increasing by 1.2%, lower than the previous high of 2%.Despite the slower growth in February, the price index reached 207.5 points, showing a 1.6% monthly increase and a 26.5% rise compared to the same time last year. Villa values rose to 269.6 points, while apartments reached 167 points, all based on a January 2021 benchmark of 100 points.
